20110119215335.000|20110119215337.000|TR0|people have the question, well, what is 
20110119215337.000|20110119215339.000|TR0|the difference?  It really depends on the 
20110119215339.000|20110119215341.000|TR0|jurisdiction you're in.

20110119215346.000|20110119215348.000|TR0|infanticide because he failed to provide 
20110119215348.000|20110119215351.000|TR0|-- or withheld medical treatment to a baby 
20110119215351.000|20110119215353.000|TR0|born alive.  And then the state goes a 
20110119215353.000|20110119215355.000|TR0|step further in saying not only did he 
20110119215355.000|20110119215357.000|TR0|fail to provide that medical treatment, he 
20110119215357.000|20110119215400.000|TR0|injured them.  He killed them afterwards.  
20110119215400.000|20110119215402.000|TR0|And so -- after they were born alive.

20110119215642.000|20110119215645.000|TR0|married in the wrong state.  She got 
20110119215645.000|20110119215647.000|TR0|married in Idaho, which is a community 
20110119215647.000|20110119215649.000|TR0|property state. And in that state, every 
20110119215649.000|20110119215652.000|TR0|spouse -- each and every spouse is 
20110119215652.000|20110119215654.000|TR0|entitled to half of the assets that were 
20110119215654.000|20110119215656.000|TR0|acquired during the marriage.  She didn't

20110119215731.000|20110119215733.000|TR0|you.  But I don't see an exception here.
